subject: Fix simultaneous timeout with smart iptables usage
commit_message:
Fix simultaneous timeout with smart iptables usage

Simultaneous boots were getting timeouts in allocate_for_network.
This was due to our inefficient use of iptables where we attempt
to recreate the same rules over and over using initialize_gateway,
plug, and restart_dhcp.

This patch makes the iptables code a little bit smarter by only
shelling out if the rule list has changed. Note that there is
a small difference in the interpretation of duplicate rules.
Previously, the last copy of the rule would win whereas now
the first copy of the rule will win. Multiple copies of the same
rule were never supported. This means the only thing that one
needs to remember is it is necessary to remove a rule and re-add
it if you want to move it later in the list.

Fixes bug 1199433

subject: Fix ratelimiting
commit_message:
Fix ratelimiting

Current master does not respect ratelimiting, since parsing of the
api-paste.ini is faulty. api-paste.ini limited user limiting by
setting a line as follows:
user:<user-id>:(GET, *, ".*", 4, minute)

This was passed to the Limiter as kwargs with "user" as a key.

the id of the user was bound to fail, since we checked on the key
with startswith("user:")

An example config in the api-paste.ini has to look as follows:
limits = (POST, "*", .*, 10, MINUTE)
limits.<user-id1>:(GET, "*", .*, 4, minute)
limits.<user-id2>:(GET, "*", .*, 2, minute)

The code has been modified to be able to handle such configs

subject: VMware: fix rescue/unrescue instance
commit_message:
VMware: fix rescue/unrescue instance

Fixes bug 1199955

The problem is due to the way in which the VM's are named on vCenter.
That is, in Nova a VM has a name and a UUID. In vCenter the VM only
has a name. The VM name on vCenter is Nova's instance UUID. When the
rescue/unrescue operation takes place a new VM is spawned/destroyed.
The Nova VM has the name '<name>-rescue'. The problem is that the
new rescue name was not passed correctly to the vCenter, that is,
it should have been '<uuid>-rescue' but it was just '<uuid>'. This
caused the opertaion to fail as there is already a VM with that name
on vCenter. A new name should have been passed which is '<uuid>-rescue'.

subject: Implement QoS support for volumes
commit_message:
Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end';
 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs;
 - Add volume/qos_specs internal API for qos specs manipulation;
 - Add 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept qos info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept qos info and do the checks.

DocImpact

subject: Ensure that setup_requires are installed
commit_message:
Ensure that setup_requires are installed

When setup.py uses easy_install to resolve dependencies, it downloads an
egg into the local dir. Additionally, when python is invoked via
sys.executable and not via a #! line, it prepends '' to sys.path. This
means that when pbr shells out to pip to install install_requirements,
it will consider any locally downloaded eggs to be installed, and so
will erroneously not install them.

To avoid this, make the pip invocation slightly more complex, and strip
'' out of sys.path in the invocation. This should mean that eggs in the
local dir will always be ignored for the purposes of resolving
dependencies, which is the correct behavior.

is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

subject: Fix instance_group_delete() DB API method
commit_message:
Fix instance_group_delete() DB API method

Table 'instance_groups' has two columns that can be used to
unambigously identify the specific row:
  - 'id' (Integer, primary_key=True, autoincrement=True)
  - 'uuid' (String)

The former is used internally to bind related instances by FKs
(InstanceGroupMember, InstanceGroupPolicy and InstanceGroupMetadata),
and the latter is accepted by public methods of DB API. This must
be a miss in DB schema design, because 'uuid' could be used for both
use cases.

instance_group_delete() deletes the instance group (and all related
instances) given its UUID value. When related entities are deleted
they are filtered by the FK value - the 'group_id' column, however,
the 'group_uuid' value is passed.

Such DELETE statement is executed successfully (though WHERE clause never
evaluates to True, so the query is logically incorrect) on MySQL and SQLite,
which are often too 'soft' when checking data types of passed values.

This patch fixes the instance_group_delete() method and renames the 'group_uuid'
argument of _instance_group_model_get_query() to 'group_id', because this one
is actually always called with id value rather than with uuid.

Closes-Bug: #1211307

Change-Id: Ic8bcb4b218f570f26420904aeb74eb14567235fb

subject: Always validate auth_uri with allowed_auth_uris
commit_message:
Always validate auth_uri with allowed_auth_uris

The original intention was to allow heat to orchestrate
on any requested cloud when allowed_auth_uris is configured
with an empty list.

This change makes all requests be validated against
allowed_auth_uris for the following reasons:
- there is a potential security issue with requests
  being authorised by a fake keystone, allowing an exploit in
  heat to be executed without any valid authentication factors
  first being presented.
- ec2token middleware will also need to be made multi-cloud aware
  however as a compatible API it is not possible to specify the desired
  auth_uri with each request. Instead ec2token will need a list of
  configured endpoints so that it can try each one until a request
  is authenticated.

Fix range GET w/If-None-Match.

An object GET request with both If-None-Match: <Etag> and
Range: bytes=N-M should result in a 304 Not Modified if the Etag
matches. However, it was resulting in a 416 Requested Range Not
Satisfiable. This commit fixes that.

The fix was to remove conditional_response=True from a request in the
proxy. As far as I can see, the only effect that
conditional_response=True has in swob is to enable range
checking. Since the object server handles all the range stuff, the
proxy shouldn't do it. Otherwise, you wind up with double-application
of the Range header, and that doesn't work very well.

insert sleeps in the tests to ensure that a cast()ed operation is

subject: Add plug-in mechanism to swift-init

Add plug-in mechanism to swift-init

While the plug-in layer for the Swift backend storage processes is being
finalized, intermediate efforts have generally supplanted the top level
executable scripts with custom implementations that will typically deviate
only slightly from the stock implementation.  This approach is both flexible
and effective; however, because it is not well defined it has a side effect of
being incompatible with swift-init.

The optional command line argument --plugin-command-prefix for swift-init will
make it possible for swift-init to manage alternative top level Swift server
executable scripts which are compatible with the stock Swift processes by
appending an alternative prefix to the name of launched script.

For example, if you install an alternative swift-object-replicator
implementation at 'mybackend-object-replicator' you can start the process from
the command line using swift-init's config and pid management with the
command:

subject: Impose a configurable size limit on raw JSON body
commit_message:
Impose a configurable size limit on raw JSON body

Currently WSGI will accept very large templates. The raw size is
not much of a concern at 4MB, but parsing that template can create a
recursive memory consumption which leads to the API server eating up
extreme amounts of memory, sometimes leading to MemoryError. Assuming
the template could pass through the API to the engine, this would also
put a heavy burden on an engine and/or the RPC system as well.

Limiting the JSON portion of the body should prevent any large templates
from entering the system.

Fixes bug #1214234

subject: Virt driver flag for different BDM formats
commit_message:
Virt driver flag for different BDM formats

This patch introduces a new virt driver property
'need_legacy_block_device_info' that will tell the compute manager if
driver needs to be passed legacy block_device_info.

This patch also refactors the compute manager methods that would pass
the block device info to driver methods - to do so according to the
property of the driver. This is done by moving all the code into a single
private method _get_instance_volume_block_device_info. This method existed
before but now uses the new DriverBlockDevice classes for it's
functionality.

As it is sometimes necessary to refresh the connection info for volume
based DriverBlockDevice objects (a private manager method
_refresh_block_device_connection_info was used for this), this patch
also factors this code to a method on the DriverVolumeBlockDeviceClass,
and is now completely used like that when needed, and removes the said
method.

Finally - this patch removes a _get_block_device_info method from the
compute API class. This remained from early pre-conductor attempts to
remove DB access from the compute service, and is irrelevant now that
conductor is used. This is needed so that the source  of block device
data is always conductor and the version of data is always
known.

After this patch - it will be possible to implement changes in drivers
that will allow them to utilise the new block device data format.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

subject: Add ext-gw-mode support to ML2
commit_message:
Add ext-gw-mode support to ML2

Closes-Bug: #1212772

ML2 doesn't support ext-gw-mode, resulting in L3 agents not
setting-up NAT rules in neutron routers (currently, l3 agents
will assume enable_snat=false if plugin doesn't provide this
parameter as described in bug 1212868)

This patchset adds the support of ext-gw-mode to ML2 plugin.

In order to support ext-gw-mode alembic migration (as well as
other potential migrations on plugin dbs), folsom_initial
migration script is fixed to include ML2 plugin. Otherwise
databases won't be set-up during migration script (but at
plugin startup by sqlalchemy), resulting in migration failures.
